channel.title: Comments on: Document Your SQL Server Databases with Extended Properties
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Scott Welker
item.dc:creator: Scott Welker
item.description: Note that "Azure SQL Database" does not support Extended Properties.
item.content:encoded: Note that “Azure SQL Database” does not support Extended Properties.

item.title: By: Bruce Dunwiddie
item.dc:creator: Bruce Dunwiddie
item.description: There are advanced scripts out there that make use of the MS_Description property that can be extended to include these custom properties, http://www.csvreader.com/posts/data_dictionary.php , etc. There are also quite a few applications that have quick editors for the MS_Description property, and some also allow editing of custom properties, http://www.sqldatadictionary.com/ , http://www.red-gate.com/products/sql-development/sql-doc/ , http://www.apexsql.com/sql_tools_doc.aspx , etc.
item.content:encoded: There are advanced scripts out there that make use of the MS_Description property that can be extended to include these custom properties, http://www.csvreader.com/posts/data_dictionary.php , etc. There are also quite a few applications that have quick editors for the MS_Description property, and some also allow editing of custom properties, http://www.sqldatadictionary.com/ , http://www.red-gate.com/products/sql-development/sql-doc/ , http://www.apexsql.com/sql_tools_doc.aspx , etc.

item.title: By: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.dc:creator: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.description: Greg - yep, they are just stored procedures. If you're trying to call them from an application - to access or add information - you call them just like any other stored procedure. Any more specific questions about that?
item.content:encoded: Greg – yep, they are just stored procedures. If you’re trying to call them from an application – to access or add information – you call them just like any other stored procedure. Any more specific questions about that?

item.title: By: Greg
item.dc:creator: Greg
item.description: Is there a way to call the extended Property functions from outside the database?
item.content:encoded: Is there a way to call the extended Property functions from outside the database?

item.title: By: Conrad Muller
item.dc:creator: Conrad Muller
item.content:encoded:
I would like to add that extended properties can be used for more than database object descriptions. Extended properties can be used to store label text for forms.

Each database column can have an extended property named “Label” to be used on forms. You fill your form labels with text from the sys tables. Then you only need to change the label text in one place to change it on every form.

item.title: By: Conrad Muller
item.dc:creator: Conrad Muller
item.content:encoded:
I have written a bunch of scripts to help me maintain extended properties in SQL Server.

http://www.databasezone.com/techdocs/dbscripts.html

Many of the scripts read the sys tables and write out all of the boilerplate extended property code ready for customization.

item.title: By: Peter Schott
item.dc:creator: Peter Schott
item.content:encoded:
On a related note, if you use SSDT to manage your schema, you can also add the definitions to the objects in your database in the “properties” panel which will be propagated into your DB.

Admittedly, that’s not nearly as detailed as what you can do using the techniques in this article, but it can be a good start for people without too much extra work.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: You can also use data modeling tools, they will add extended properties in the script without you having to do this manually by calling sys.sp_addextendedproperty. <br /> With ERwin you need to use a macro but Sybase PowerDesigner does it automatically
item.content:encoded:
You can also use data modeling tools, they will add extended properties in the script without you having to do this manually by calling sys.sp_addextendedproperty.
With ERwin you need to use a macro but Sybase PowerDesigner does it automatically
